Pours black into a tulip. Mocha micro head with excellent retention recedes leaving trailing lacing. Roasted pit fruit, chocolate and peat aromas. Medium bodied with toffee, roasted nuts and a lasting sweet smoked peat finish.

Bottle from bestillingsutvalget, Vinmonopolet.  Very dark brown with a ruby shade. Firm choco head. Well roasted dark malts and a light peat on the nose. A whiff of dark dried fruits and wood. Taste is medium to heavily roasted dark malt. Pepper and tar tones, and hints of rum&raisin, wood and smoke. Medium strong, softly carbonated body. Complex finish. Elegant, tasty and well balanced.
bottle 12904 (07*11) at home 5/11/11 Grassy and grainy rye nose with a hint of maraschino cherry. Overwhelming whisky flavour, very warming but thinner bodied than the preceding expressions.

Taste and aroma is somewhat complex and ranges from coffee to fruits, theres also caramel and even vanilla in there. It might just be my imagination, but I thought I felt something that resembles the smoothness of a whiskey in the mouthfeel. Pours a dark brown colour and supports a minimal brown head. (Bottle)

33cl bottle. Pitch black colour with small head.  Aroma is more alcohol than the 12. Malts, dark chocolate and caramel again. Faint hints of oak.  Flavour is more intense notes of the chocolate and oak in the 12. More liqorice and some smoke here. Some burnt rubber. Some raisins and other dried fruits. Medium long aftertaste.

Bottle...330ml...2nd Ola Dubh for me :P .....Pours pitch black with small creamy tan head.... the aroma is port, roasted malt, whisky and some dark chocolate.... the flavor is notes of whiskey, some smoked bacon, dark chocolate, roasted malt.... love this one to.... :) nice well made....

Bottled 330ml. -from Biererei, Vienna. Vintage 2009. Bottle No. 34152
Black coloured, medium sized brown head, roasted malt nose with hint of whisky. Roasted malt, chocolate and dried fruits with notes of whisky and alcohol. Light nutty and smoky finish. Delicious brew.

Smell of caramel, licorice and alcohol, very rich. Blackish-brown with minimal, mid-brown head. Aroma of toasted rye, licorice and leaves, maybe some wood. Medium sweet and heavily bitter. Palate is sharp and long, oily texture. Quite excellent and very soft and round after all, despite being a heavy and dark one.

Sampled at Gothenburg Beer Festival 2011. September 3, 2011

Whisky aromas with notes of raisin, spices, vanilla, the wood from barrel ageing and light caramel. Doesnt feel as vivid as the 16 year version but the aromas are still nice. The mouthfeel is a bit flater but still nice with loads of whisky.

11.2 fl oz bottle generously given to me by mhill2079. JAN 2009 bottle date stamped on label. The pour is black, hints of maroon, and a smallish khaki head. The head falls loosely. The aroma is sweet syrup malt, a very faint hint of soy and a nicely gentle waft of the whisky and the wood. As it warms, a smoke is evident that helps to balance the initial sweetness.  The taste has more of the Whisky notes - smoke and peat are up front, turning too the soy sweet syrup of the nose, fading back to the wood and smoke and the loose finish.  The integration of flavors is well done, though some of that is lost in the finish. The palate is medium to heavy bodied, low (almost still) carbonation and the finish which sort of breaks down into sweet, smoke and booze. Tasty stuff, thanks Mike.

Bottle, sample.
Black with a small, porous tan head.
Aroma: nice whiskey notes with red berries and chocolate.
Taste: milk chocolate, cocoa, creamy, liqueurish, not that much whisky.
Above medium-bodied, smooth.
Not one of my favourites in the series.

0.33l bottle. This one pours a dark dark brown - near black oily body with a nice little bubbly and sidesticking light chocolate-head. Aroma is fantastic. Woody, peat, beautiful sweet smoky whisky, notes of dark caramel and some thin hints of alcohol and chocolate. Really nice! It has a average carbonation level, medium-bodied and a nice oily mouthfeeling. Tastes are dominated by licorice and chocolate with notes of light smoke, wood and perhaps some cold coffee as well. Ends mild bitter with more hints of nice smoke, thin alcohol and some light burned wood. Its leaving a long lasting chocolate- and perhaps a bit watery aftertaste. Fantastic!

Bottled 0.33L. Mild nose with some hints of vanilla and chocolate and syrop. Pale brownish head with large bubbles. Thin and fast disappearing. Dark black colour. Slightly sour and whiskey taste. Also malty and roastiness. Also some smokeyness and some hints of vanilla in the taste.

Bottle from vinmonopolet. Pours pitch black with a huge light tanned head. Aroma is peaty, wood, whisky and dark malts. Taste is moderate sweet, chocolate, smooth peaty, liquorice. Lingering caramel malty end. Not bad, but i prefer the 16 years old over this.

Bottle from BrewFellas in Nicosia.  Very dark brown.  The aroma is very whiskeyish, with lots of oil, smokey notes, creosote, wood and some chocolate.  Smokey, maybe a bit thin, a little smokey.  Oily, slightly chocolatey finish.

Bottle. Pours a near-black deep brown body with a fantastic, multi-layered head: mocha-hued in the bottom and creamy white on top. Very nice. In the nose, whisky aromas immediately appear, along with wood, dark malts and roasty caramel notes. Taste is velvety smooth notes of licorice, wood, whisky and hints of chocolate and burnt toast. Some roasted nuts in the finish, which is much smoother than the 16 year old version; this one has a lot more whisky and mellow tones in it. Warming alcohol in the aftertaste, along with long-lasting wooden notes. A great beer from the Ola Dubh series.

Aroma: Tar, fudge, dried apricot, coffe, vanilla.
Taste: Salmiac, fudge, tar, cassis, fresh apple, vanilla, raisins, milk chocolate.
Mouthfeel: Full body, a bit too fizzy.

Bottle courtesy of unclemike.  Not sure how this beer is sitting so low.  Great looking beer right off the bat.  Dark brown color, nice tan head that leaves plenty of lacing.  Wonderful sweet aroma with mild whiskey, caramel, and toffee and slight hints of cigar.  Flavor is a smooth mixture chocolate, vanilla, malts, mild whiskey, and smooth cigar like flavor.  Palate is up to par with the rest of the beer if just tad watery.  An amazing beer, plenty of complexity yet smooth and mellow.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2011 33 cl bottle, BBE 201Z (sic!), bottled JAN 2009. Rated on 24.6.2011
Tasting of all Ola Dubh versions from 12 to 40 and Old Engine Oil as a reference. This was better than 16 or 40, but worse than 12 or 30.
Aroma has whisky, which is more coarse than 12 or 16 but still kind of nice. Flavour has whisky too, but it has a bit loose connection with the beer.
Bottle from Alko Arkadia. Originally rated on 3.7.2010. Okay barrel aged beer, but not the greatest of the series.

2009 bottling.  Pours black, slight tan head fades to a ring.  Aroma is mildly of whisky, prunes, and chocolate.  Flavor is almond nougat, chocolate, more prunes, and a whisky, smokey finish.  Not as full bodied as expected.  Would have been great if it had been a bit fuller in the mouth.  Instead, just good.  Would like to try a "new" bottle of the 18 year.

Bottled. Dark brown almost black with a small firm beige foam. Rich rounded aroma of toasted malts, oak, roasted almonds, prunes, sweet licorice and milky chocolate. Nearly full-bodied with strong notes of malt whiskey, oak, nuts, almonds and roasted malts with touches of anise, toasted bread and mild coconut. Smooth mouthfeel. Long aftertaste of wood, whiskey, roasted almonds, mild anise and toasted malts

Bottle 33 cl. Poured very dark brown/black in colour with thin beige head. Roasted coffee, peat, smoke and sea salt in aroma. Whiskey notes and some faint hints of sweetness also. Oily texture. Leaves a thin but slowly fading lacing on the glass. Quite strong whiskey and smokey tones in aroma actually. Stunningly perfect. Flavour is filled with roasted coffee, whiskey and smoke. At first a very intense flavour of these three but somehow how it got mellow towards the end, pehaps a bit too much. A bit too sweet also in the end. Served this together with some bourbon vanilla icecream and they seemed to work well together. Great dessert like that or then on its own.
Bottle. Aromas caramel whisky earthy roasted malts. Pours very black with a thin head but a very oily body. Medium sweet taste. A very complex and interesting brew.

In short: Creamy nutty chocolate fudge with  plenty of whisky barrel.  Good smooth beer
How: Bottle 12oz.  Consumed more than one year after bottling date.
The look: Near black body topped by a small persistent tan head
In long: Nose is big far creamy black malts, barrels, notes of tar, black chocolate.  Taste of creamy chocolate fudge, rich caramel, whisky barrels, peat, tar, vanilla, hazelnuts, crème de menthe (Im not kidding).  Carbonation is very soft.  The beer is obviously quite sweet but somehow it didnt bother me, something bout its minty character prevented it from being cloying.  Overall the beer is not very tasty for a BA 8% beer, it is actually pretty smooth.  I wish girl names would be like  Ola Dubh beers and have the number of years in brackets, that would have saved me a lot of trouble.

Bottled. Dark color with a very nice beige head, aroma is too complex, notes of whiskey malt, chocolate, coffee, caramel, wood, roasted malt. Flavor is woody and roasted malty, something else that I have no idea. :) Mouthfeel is quite dry with a smooth whiskey malt at end. Very nice beer. Expensive in Brazil. R$26,50 ( 11,50).
33 Bottle at a Bishops Arms in Goteberg. Both the whiskey smell and flavor is far more subdued in the 18 year than the 30 but still an excellent beer. (Rated offline 2011/04/17)

At a tasting, thanks Ariel, pours brown to black with a chocolate color head, aroma of honey, wood, chocolate, caramel and Werthers Original, flavor of burnt wood, fresh wood, brandy and coffee, light acidity in between, medium to full bodied, Nice.

11.2oz bottle split with mcberko. Pours dark brown/red. Aroma of syrup, raisins, red wine, dark fruits, smoke. Flavour of smoke, chocolate, some sweetness there too. Lively, yet also soft on the tongue.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2011 11.2 oz. bottle, split with Matts_Property, pours deep dark brown with a reddish tinge and small tan head. Extremely rich and complex aroma of whiskey, caramel, dark fruits, smoke and wood. Flavour brings out the smokiness on top, with leather, whiskey barrels, slight molasses, toasted nuts and maybe some subtle very dry dark fruits. Smokey, dry finish that leaves the barrels on top. Excellent.

Bottle. Creamy lightbrown good  mostly lasting head. Black colour. Moderate malty and light hopy aroma. Some prune and whisky notes. Moderate bitter slightly messy flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate.

330ml bottle 
8.0% ABV 
Best Before: January 2012 
I tried this beer on March 8, 2011 after purchasing from the Queens Quay LCBO outlet in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a solid black with a short-lived tan coloured head.  The aroma is roasted malt, nuts, and coffee...very very similar to the 16 Year Old version.  Mouthfeel is full-bodied, creamy, with medium carbonation.  The flavour is smoke, roasted malt, nuts, coffee, and again finished with the taste of whiskey.  I really cant tell a difference between the 16 and the 18 (aside from the $1.00 in price)....both are very good beers.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2011 Quick re-rate. Bottled September 2009. Thanks to savvy1982. Awesome ashes in the aroma, with nice peat and chocolate, Taste is pretty much the same but less harsh than what I had last time. Same quality as most of the others of the series which I love. Great taste amazing finish. Packed with flavor but still rather drinkable, no alcohol. Great complex and lengthy finish. Awesome beer. Im definitely a big fan of this.

330ml bottle from I dont remember who. Bottled Jan 2009.
Appearance : Pitch black with a medium foamy and creamy head. Light lacing.

Aroma : Great chocolate with ashes and peaty smoke. Light hops. Great nose.

Taste : Smoke and ashed with wood. Light chocolate. Big ashes on finish, a bit harsh. Nice peaty smoke with light hops and some alcohol.

Overall : Great nose, nice smoke and chocolate. A bit too much ash though. Taste felt a bit unbalanced. Too much ashes and alcohol. Gets a bit better after an hour in the glass. Feels a bit young bit its already 2 years old so Im wondering if itll ever get smoother. Im usually a fan of their old ales but this one is a bit disappointing... 8,3,7,3,15; 3.6 May 2011
Bottle at Wachi. Nice whiskey, malt, caramel aroma, with dried fruitsraisins. Smoky, malty flavor with rich chocolate, slight sweetned coffee. Smooth and rich.

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks Ariel. Dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, some chocolate, molasses, dark fruits, whisky and wood notes. Sweetish roasty flavor with some chocolate, nuts, some smoke, wood and fruity notes. Medium-bodied.

In my fridge for at least 5 months. Like all the dubhs it pours a dark mahogany brown with a short lived beige head. And just like the all the other dubhs, the place this stuff really shines is in the aroma. This one is heavy on the anise and licorice, love it, then theres the smoke and peat which always baffles me because I rarely find highlands smokey or peaty. . . but i like it, beef jerky, chocolate, malt, awesome. The flavour is really good, probably not worth what I payed for, but a unique and delicious experience non the less. Heavy on the beef jerky flavours, smoke and peat all the way through, light notes of chocolate and anise, finishs with more smoke. Awesome stuff!

Bottle 31586 July 2009. Opened April 29, 2011. Pours black, small head, not so thick looking. Gorgeous sexy aroma of charcoal, iodine, a cannabis roach, the resin from a pipe, tobacco, and Scottish peat. Im tempted to say the aroma is like bong water, but that would sound bad and its a great aroma, it just reminds me of really really good bong water. Deep roast and long lingering iodine. The tobacco and cannabis resins are lovely on the tongue, and there is a lot of nice dryness in the finish, and aftertaste like i just smoked a joint and the lingering smoke is permeating. Then there is prune in the background. I love Ola Dubhs.

330 ml bottle from LCBO (side-by-side with 16 and 30). Pours a very dark, opaque brown with modest-sized tan head. Aroma is chocolate, brown sugar, light roast and fruit, and some whiskey/oak. Flavour starts with cocoa, light brown sugar and mild fruit; whiskey/oak from the cask comes through towards the end. Thinner than I might have anticipated, but decent body all the same. Didnt find huge differences between the three - this one had a little fruitiness I didnt pick up in the other two.  Nice.

Oily black substance slid into my glass. The small yet thick and velvety soft brown crown stayed compact and leaves and constantly replenishes the amount of ropy lacing. WOW! Man, I love this! Silky smooth chocolate aroma, sensual toffee, subdued scotch, shit loads of nuts, light smoke - Im drooling constantly! This is one of the best smelling beers I have ever encountered. Tons of nuts, almonds - awesome. The taste is not a letdown after the amazing aroma that felt me up. Creamy, smooth, very nutty, almonds, light zippy spice? shat is it? nice mild scotch, vanilla. Damn! The last 1/4 glass is VERY soothing now... lovely. Warm apple without any spice. Smooth light zippy bite of bitterness, Drying, light roasted malts. A truly heavenly experience.

As a big time whiskey fella when I saw this bottle at whole foods figured I had to grab.  Nose is chocolate and toffee with some peat.  The pour is jet black with small beige head.  Taste amazingly of whiskey and peat smoke, dark chocolate, vanilla, caramel.  Mouthfeel is great I dont find it too thick at all.  Great first beer from Scotland for me

Bottled.  Poured clear, deep brown with garnet highlights and an easily-resuscitated tan head.  The aroma was almost all whiskey.. with peaty and nutty notes leading.. warm feel, with miscellaneous roasted black malts beneath.. I dug the whiskey, but it very much masked the underlying brew.  The flavor found sweeter whiskey sugars, aged oak, and vanilla throughout.. black patent, nutty, and lesser chocolate malts on the light-moderately roasted core.. tangy whiskey and oak plus some residual black sugars on the long, whiskey-y finish.. tasty, but again there was too much barrel influence.  Medium-bodied at most on the palate.. fairly slick, with low carbonation (I dont know where "gloopy and viscous" comes from).. decent feel and flow.. overall this was a solid drinker, but it was far from exceptional.

Bottle at the Rake. It pours pitch black with a thin tan head. The nose is liquorice, charcoal, caramel, cherry, fig and date. It tastes of caramel, rich-roast coffee, toffee, Scottish tablet, wood, liquorice root, vanilla, cola and brown sugar. The alcohol is very well hidden and the body is lighter than expected. It is pretty dangerous stuff as its so easy to drink.

330ml Bottle (Bottle #: 0577.  Bottled: 2/2009.):  Complex aroma of malt, peat, wood, slight chocolate, slight whiskey, slight roasting, slight tar, almonds, and a hint of soy sauce.  Poured pitch black in color with a small, creamy, dense, tan head that greatly diminished but lasted throughout, especially around the edges.  Opaque.  Lightly sparkling.  Flavor is medium sweet and slightly bitter.  Tastes of malt, light roasting, light tar, peat, light wood, slight whiskey, slight vanilla, and a hint of smoke.  Medium to full body.  Dry texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Malt, light roast, slight smoke, light wood, slight tar finish is dry.  8%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Aroma is toffee, caramel, vanilla, cream, slight smoke/peat, alcohol. Upfront roasted flavor, finishes with a scotch-like dryness. Very pleasant flavors of toffee, caramel, peat, smoke. Creamy mouthfeel. Flavors keep on going in this once. Scotch flavors really shine in the finish. Very thought-provoking beer.

Looks better than the 12 year - slightly better head retention. Also, more elegant on the nose and palate. Treacle and chocolate aromas. Then chocolate, cream and the whisky flavours. The palate shows a big structure, a very creamy texture and a more elegant finish, though with some whisky alcohol burn.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2011 black, thin dark tan head. doesnt look as syrupy as the 12 yo.
choc oakiness has picked up a fruit aroma
thin/med body and slightly fizzy. not as syrupy as the 12yo
less wood means you get more beer. choc stout tastes are showing above the oak.


dark w/ a thin head
smells outstanding! rich and oaky
not as thick as the 16yo but more so than the 12yo
tastes just like the 16yo
theyre both great beers but i think the 16yo is a bit thicker

On tap at Sergios. Really sweet aroma of toffee, nougat, sweet chocolate and butterscotch. Appearance was black with light tan head. Flavor emphasized the sweet aromas, but with some slight whiskey sourness on the backside of all that sweetness. Palate was bubbly and terminated creamy. Certainly good, just a little overkill on the sweetness for me. If you love sweet beers, this may be up your alley.

11-FEB-2011, bottle @home, with Ulkløbben, from "Fish & Beer".
Served blind with Old Engine Oil and Ola Dubh 40.
Whiskey is really present on this one. But its like barrel aging a beer that is a littel too simple does not make it a better beer. Still a little thin and not really complex enough. Would gladly drink it again, but I will not go out seeking the others in the series.

Bottle at The Nook.  Pours opaque with an average, fizzy beige head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, chocolate, roasted), light hops (herbal), and average esters (fruity) with notes of smoke, wood, alcohol, and vanilla.  Flavor is heavy malt (cookie, chocolate, coffee, roasted), light hops (earthy), and average esters (fruity) with notes of smoke, wood, alcohol, and vanilla.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation, low creaminess with a dry finish.

Bottle from The Cave. Strong aroma of sweet malts & alcohol. Very dark brown colour like oily cola. Flavor very complex - sweet & spicy roasted malts & treacle toffee with pleasant ligering aftertaste and very smooth. A very different beer which is really good.

Harviestoun Ola Dubh Special Reserve 18 is a robust old ale age in 18 year old whiskey casks. It pours a deep black color, and the Scotch whiskey aroma jumps right out at you in the nose. The Scotch whiskey is also very prevalent in the taste, and is complimented by dark chocolate, sweet malt, and a vanilla oakiness at the finish. I have friends, whore fans of bourbon and whisky aged stouts, that would love this ale. Id even bet that Scotch whiskey drinkers would appreciate it as well.

Like the other dubhs, there is a big aroma of oak, and vanilla, but there is a big dufference in the intensity of these flavors compared to the 30 and 40. The roastiness seems more upfront, more like a robust porter. A thick soy aftertaste, and lots of bitter coffee.

330ml bottle from LCBO. Pours a solid black with thin ring of cream head. Aroma is barrel, vanilla, woody and sweet, some light notes of fruit. Flavour is extreme peat smoke, sweet malt. Some barrel notes and vanilla. Scarily drinkable, really fantastic stuff.

Bottle. Whisky and wooden aroma.  Very dark appearance even when looking though the very bottom of a trappist glass (black oil indeed)
Less syrupy than expected but leaves a nice whisky aftertaste.

draft at Blue Monk, Buffalo. Beautiful looking dark black pour, khaki head. Chocolate & roasted malts, Scotch. Taste was the above but with an off acidic tartness. Sharpe off  bite amonst all the other intended flavor, too bad. Will rerate with a bottle.

Bottle #16096, brewed January 2009. 33 cL from the LCBO courtesy of Rob and Pat, served in a snifter. Pours black with a small light brown head. The head fades slowly to a bare cover but leaves a small amount of fine lace. On the nose, there are aromas of molasses, whisky, and chocolate with hints of espresso, herbs and cask wood. The flavour is moderately sweet with complex notes of whisky, roasted malts, molasses, and espresso. The flavour is balanced with a good dose of herbal hops. The finish is long, lingering whisky with just a touch of hops. On the palate, it is full in body with a milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice roasty ale with a strong whisky accent in the latter half. The whisky is more prominent than in the 12 or 18 year old.  Another very well made beer with a beautiful smooth and elegant body, ample roasted malts and nicely complementary whisky notes. 2011-01-14

330 ml bottle from LCBO, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. SEP 2012. 
App.:  Deep brown black with a small light mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Tons of deep, rich, fruity molasses, definitely some peat smoke, but in an either tired or integrated way, iodine, brothy, thick, savoury, green notes, really thick and inky and sweet and dark.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, restrained, velvety effervescence, slightly syrupy and also a touch chalky.
  
Flav.:  More smoke than the nose, but still feels...muted or warn-out somehow, plenty of thick, inky, fruity molasses, still plenty of iodine and savoury/meaty/mashy/brothy notes, some dark chocolate peeks through, an interesting blend of dark malts and Scotch smoke, pretty good; sweet with almost enough bitterness (not cloying, but a touch flaccid), sweet chocolate some molasses and a bit of peat smoke.

I could probably make a joke or two about 18 year olds, but I think Ill just shut up and drink my beer.

Middle of the pack enjoyment of the series.  Must do a vertical one night.  Pours black, wiskey smoke aromas.  Milk chocolate taste, a little more bitter at the end of the bottle.  Bit more than medium mouthfeel.  Whiskey is right there.Good drinkability.

Bottle from The Cave. Strong aroma of sweet malts & alcohol. Very dark brown colour like oily cola. Flavor very complex - sweet & spicy roasted malts & treacle toffee with pleasant ligering aftertaste and very smooth. A very different beer which is really good.

33cl bottle.  Well what do you expect when you add a slug of 18 yo Highland Park single malt into a sizeable old ale? Something delectable provided the beer that is added to the cask is good enough, and this is.  Not so much whisky notes as chords. Rich dark textures come from the ale side.
Smoky, leathery and slightly chocolatey aroma.  Peat smoke, vanilla, chocolate, hazelnut in the taste.  This is a  well made beer and is beautifully balanced.

Bottle 330 ml  2009 vintage # 15016 
Aroma dark ,straight smoky feel with touch of plum , barley roast , dark soy. Light hint of whiskey barrel.7+
 Appearance  clear dark brown look with medium head, dark beige , fine top. 4-
Flavor and Palate : Medium bodied. Frontal dryness with hint of ash followed by burnt barley grains , cask feel. Clean character , mellow bodied with refined smooth dry toast on top. Sweeter sugars with alcohol shown at finish. Felt lighter on alcohol than numbers suggested. Bonus for being very drinkable.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2010 Bottle: Pours a deep black with a decent coffee colored cap. Mild carbonation. Aroma has the same smoked peaty-oak cask aromas as the 30 and 40 yr reserve but the dried fruit notes seem brighter in this 16 year version. Flavour profile confirms this one has more dried fruit tones come forward in the front. Still wonderful complexity in the middle as roasty malts and vinous esters mingle with smokey peaty oak tones. Finish is long and oily on the palate with a dozen different compound flavours poking away at the palate. Covers the alcohol well and gives a satisfying warming.

Still a decadent brew but at a price most can afford.

Bottle via Savvy1982. Near black in colour with moderate carbonation. Aromas are of peaty scotch cask, chocolate, and a bit of sherry. Flavours are of peat, creosote, caramel, chocolate, ash, plum, and faint mineral. Medium bodied. More restrained than the 12 year old, but still has a huge Highland Park influance. The sherry note on the nose was a bit of a negative for me personally, but not really out of place as far as intentions go. Quite nice, but I prefer the 12 y.o.

Bottle - 330ml. Opaque black body with a thin beige foamy/creamy head. Rich malty/hoppy aroma with cocoa and vanilla hints. Alcohol is well hidden. Taste carries some whisky, fruity, woody, and subtle roasty notes. It leaves a long, warming bittersweet aftertaste. Very enjoyable!
Aroma is lots of whiskey with some roasted malt. Flavour is peat, with roasted malt/chocolate and somewhat cigar-like.  Really smooth and only a hint of booze. Great stuff.

330 mL bottle.  (bb Jan 31, 2012).  Deep, dark chestnut brown.  The small, brown head doesnt last long, but laces nicely.  The aroma is lovely, with milk chocolate, oak/scotch, and nuts.  The flavour is equally as fantastic, with lots of scotch and smoke, chocolate, alcohol, vanilla, and sweet caramel.  Mouthfeel is creamy, but not as full as expected.  Very attractive beer.

This is probably the best beer I have had ever. Extremely viscous oily pour with a deep black body and a nice creamy two fingers of tan head. Aroma is huge peaty smoke with deep alcohol and malts. Bitter alcohol with huge character. Thick mouthfeel and delcious scotch peat taste. I love this beer.

Foggy dark brown and reddy-cognac highlights, just a little dark tan head, light carbonation. Aroma is lightly scotch-like and sweet. Taste at first is lightly woody and tannic with a dilute dry feel. Develops elements of oak char, peat, tar, toffee, sweet black fruits and a more mellow woodiness, some alcohol and a natural woody earthy dry finish. A slight green note sits uncomfortably above the oddly light palate. I need to continue drinking it to form any impression, taking time to build but still an interesting and valid experiment.

Tasted 2010-11-06. Part of an old ale tasting at Einar & Guddie. Much like the 16, but perhaps a bit more oaky. Whisky is very much present. Tobacco and vanilla makes it about as smooth as beer can be. Around our table, this seemed to be a mans beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours black with some red-orange corners and a lovely beige head. The aroma is amazingly mouthwatering: smoky beef brisket and charcoal dominate, then some distant notes of cocoa, raisin, coffee, vanilla, and leather. The flavor is rich, smoky meat all around. Oh man it makes me hungry. Combined with that aroma, a sizzling, fatty cut of well-smoked brisket is all I can think about. There are some notes of cocoa, raisin, vanilla, and cola in there, as well. The finish brings campfire smoke, nuts, a slight salty wood note. Man this is good.

Bottle no 481, bottling date feb 2009. I never tried this when it was somewhat fresh, but I think this is past its prime as its feeling a lot thinner than I expected. What is there is good though. A deep dark brown beer enters the glass and creates a light brown head that settles to a foam ring after a while, leaving lots of small lacings. On the nose is plenty of soft, fudgey whisky, softly roasted malts and chocolate. It is a little thin in the mouthfeel, almost watery in the end, but the tastes are nice having everything from the aroma plus almonds and oats. If this had a bigger body to match its flavours, it would be a great beer. Maybe it once was?

Smaken är like kul och like rökig som doften. I tillägg till ek och tjära, hittar jag hints av kaffe och choklad. Själva vätskan är en aning tunn, men det var en jätte kul öl att ha provat. Roligt med något annorlunda för en gångs skuld.

Bottled on Date: Feb. 2009. Poured opaque black/brown, with only a small batch of bubbles for a head. Aroma: rye, whiskey saturated wood, old roasted malts, dark fruits, vanilla, almost sweet.... fuck all, this smells gooood! Taste: old roasted malts, whiskey saturated wood, rye, vanilla, creamy, sweet, notes of bitter dark chocolate and raisin. Medium-ish body. Nice warm, mellow finish. Very balanced, great depth. Overall: Excellent. If this was $5.00 cheaper a bottle I would drink it every day. However, it is worth the extra few dollars.
Bottle. Black with small tan head. Flavour is roasted malt, vinous, coffee, chocolate and notes of whiskey.

(Bottle) Very dark brown colour, almost black, with hints of ruby when seen through light. Creamy beige head. Roasted, malty nose with lots of chocolate  and notes of vanilla, oak, dark rye bread, raisins and hints of oak wood, whisky and dark rhum. Malty, slightly roasted taste with chocolate, dried fruit, raisins, vanilla, coffee with cream, liquorice and hints of oak wood and malt whisky. Slighly vinous finish with a touch of warming alcohol and a gentle coffee bitterness. More than medium body, smooth and velvety moutfeel. Some sweetness. As with all the other Ola Dubh beers, the subtle wood ageing makes the beer sensationally well balanced and very tasty. Brilliant!

Bottle 33 cl from Vom Fass in Fribourg (CH). Quite black with small tan head. Complex nose of oak, licorice, earthy, dark fruits and tar. The palate is rich, fruity but roasted. Oily texture, there are chocolate, whisky, blackcurrant, toffy, tobacco with notes of vanilla and peat. Long and velvety finale, with raisin, old plum and salty key. Great !

Bottle. Dark brown, lazy brown densely packed head. Aroma is quite boozy, sweet prunes, a little earthy. Flavours of stewed fruits, light scotch, peat, leather, light smoke, and dusty old wood. The dustiness really dominates the finish, to the point of conferring a muddy sensation. Dry, mildly bitter finish. Not as rich or as well-balanced as the 12 or the 30.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Colour: Quite dark with dark thick lacing. Nose: port, grape juice, rubber, stale coffee. Taste: Immediate fusion of smoked rubber and oyster. Old dry wood, heaps of malt, and a touch of maraschino cherry make up the middle. Finish has distinct charcoal taste and mouth feel. Very unique, very distinct. Very good parts, very bad parts.

330ml bottle picked up at Brewforia 
Appearance: Pours dark brown with a nice beige head and some lacing 
Aroma: Dark malts and fruit, whiskey and chocolate 
Taste: Thin mouthfeel. Dark malts, oak and metallic 
Nice

Bottle thanks to Craig. Drank blind with the 40 yr. Pours a dark color with a medium beige head. A nice nose of sweet chocolates, old musty barrels. The flavor is somewhat thin; sweet chocolates, whiskey bite, light smoke. Earthy, somewhat hot.

On tap at Mekong for the 15th Anniversary Party on 08/19/2010. Dark black body with a small brown head. Big malt and chocolate aroma. Huge scotch flavor with light salty and peat notes. Medium full body with moderately low carbonation.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2010 (bottle) pours a very dark brown colour with a small light brown head. very rich and complex aroma of treacle, liquorice, chocolate fudge and toffee, with some notes of charcoal, peat and earth. flavour is more on the earthy side of things, with toasted grain, coffee, chocolate icing and some hints of iodine in the background, though perhaps just a little too rich and sweet. strong-bodied with average carbonation. a slow sipper.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2010 Sample at Jackie Os BBDA and Oil of Aphrodite Release and Barrel aged Beer Festival on 9/11/10. Pours a dark chestnut color with a medium thick beige head that diminishes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Smoky malt aroma with notes of dark fruit, caramel and oak. Full body with flavors of scotch, peaty malt, caramel, figs and fruit. The finish is rich and malty with a lingering raisin and nut aftertaste. Solid from start to finish.

Sample during Jackie Os BBDA and Oil of Aphrodite Release and Barrel aged Beer Festival on 9/11/10. Darkest brown to black pour with no head. Strong whiskey aroma with some dark fruit and chocolate. Roasty malt flavor with some caramel malt and a bit of fruit before a boozy finish.

Pour is black with little to no head.  Aroma fronts smoke, soil, black coffee, black pepper, cigar ash.  Sexy.  Mouthfeel is too light to support those aromatic notes.  Flavor is bittersweet; bakers chocolate crossed with cigar smoke and mineral-rich soil.  A bit dead right through the middle.  Finish ripens again with pronounced Scotch-barrel elements and earthiness, ending long and complex.
Draft at Maxs.  Very dark brown, tan edge head.  Aroma of pine treated with creosote.  Taste is smooth chocolate, scotch, wood.  Nice.

Shared with Travlr, on draft. Thick black with minimal head. Nothing significant in the aromas, perhaps a touch of chocolate and vanilla. Flavors are sweet, caramel, coffee with a hint of bitterness on the back end. Nice burnt flavors linger through the aftertaste.

Received a single 330 ml bottle (#09189) via SecretSanta. Pours an opaque dark brown, nearly black colored brew with a thin tan head that quickly dissipates to a film top and no ring. Aroma of mostly scotch whiskey with a mild smoked peat scent compared to the younger 16-year version. Taste is the same as its aroma. More whiskey and peat flavors on a thick, full bodied dark malt beverage with some metallic and charcoal character. Finish is slick with a distinct scotch whiskey aftertaste that really overpowers the dark malt flavor.

Bottle. Pours clear black. Thin pale tan head, very weak spotty lacing. This is far more subtle than the 12, much more like the 30. For some reason the barrel is more obvious here wheras the 12 was a joygasm in my mouth, this is more like reading Hemingway, fascinating and intense, but ultimately kind of a downer. Nose is straight-up Highland Park, plus a light smoky dark-malt thing, some raisin, toffee, and smoke also. Very complex, but not as hedonistically enjoyable as the 12. Flavours are tight and flavourful, mildly vinous, plus booze, lots of smoke especially as it warms up, showing the peat. Really complex, and thoroughly enjoyable.

Pours black with a thin beige head. Amazing aroma with  strong whiskey notes. Lots of dark malt on the nose. Great mouth feel. Sweet and malty giving to a strong oak flavour with a great oak flavour and strong whiskey notes. Sweet lingering highland park flavour. Great!!

Aroma is much more wet than the 12, heavy, its darker but not sweeter or thicker at all. Very dark, not much on C02, but it doesnt need it really, its sort of got a spirit essence to the flavour. Also wood is definatley present. Its thin and surpising next to the 12, which was much more complex. Good, but the 12 was better and cheaper. thouch entirely different.
Thanks again to Skyview!  Black color with a small head.  Light peat smoke aroma.  Salty, smoky, roasty flavor.  Full bodied.  No grand difference from the others.
T hanks Skyview!  Dark black poor. Delicate chocolate aroma with lots of whiskey.the body is low carbonated. Nice balanced flavor.

Sample courtesy of Blazer06. Pours deep darkness with mahogany edges and tiny off white head. The aroma is rich with prune slurry, molasses, chocolate, earthiness, a mild level of roasty malts and a bit of heat at the end of the draw. The taste has a thin body to start with and stirs up notes of chocolate, roasted malts, earthiness and molasses. These notes quickly give up ground to a thicket of peatiness and a mild level of smoke.

11.2 oz. bottle- Pours black as black with a thin tan head that recedes almost immediately, lacework is nothing special. Aroma is black licorice, wood oak and molasses, the flavor is chocolate malt, licorice, followed by oakey notes, but not too strong. This beer is smooth, I was a little worried when I smelled the aroma, Ive had these beers when they come out flat and lifeless, but this is excellent, carbonation is spot on, will buy the other year reserve series brews. I am actually suprised of the alcohol content, I thought a beer of this caliber would be higher.

Bottle. Looks great although the foam is quickly sinking. Alcohol and prune aroma is not as nice as the 12; just a bit off like dark fruit going off in the bowl. Sweet dark flavour is not as smooth, more dark over ripe fruit trying to entice you in?! Tasty but thin and a dark fruit undercurrent that does not quite blend in.

thanks blazer06 for the share.
Jan 09 bottle.
dark brown, tan head.
aroma, smoked malts, wood, touch of chocolate and booze.
flavors, similar to aroma, smoked / chocolate malts, bordering the char/peat aspect and a mix of whiskey flavors. Carbonation was low but fitting for the style.
Cask  flavors, a touch of soy, dry palate.

Thanks blazer06 for this one.  Pours dark brown with tan head.  Nose is malt, tobacco, peat, cherry, roast, ash, and some whiskey.  Flavor is similar with tobacco, ash, cherries, and peat in the background coming forward periodically.  Not as ridiculously peaty as some of the other Ola Dubh.
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2015 Smokey Scotch whisky. Very warming.  Manages to avoid being too cloying.  Very Nice. Serving: Bottle

[bottle # 11073, Jan 2009]
nose is full of roasted malt--coffee and burnt potatoes--along with licorice, vanilla, and oak.
opaque brown with thin beige head.
flavor is a mellow blend of sweet, sour, and bitter--with tons of smoke and wood.
medium bodied, super dry and astringent, wood finish.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is lightly malty (caramel, bread), with light notes of smoke, wood, vanilla, cardboard.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

There really isnt much to it...the aroma is very light and while whats there certainly isnt unpleasant, it doesnt yield much to entice the ol nostrils.  The mouth experience is perfectly acceptable but kind of light and bland.  I certainly admire subtlety, but "dull" isnt quite the same thing. An instantly forgettable beer, but I imagine the packaging and concept is very appealing to many.  I had the 16 a little over a year ago and it was equally forgettable.

Nearly opaque black color with a small, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, smoked malts, wood, peat, chocolate, and some alcohol.  Taste of peat smoke, roast, coffee, wood, smoked malts, and light alcohol in the finish.

11.2 ounce bottle, bottled in January 2009, bottle # 09207.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours dark brown with about a 1/4 inch tan head that went away pretty quickly.  There is a good bit of lacing.  Aroma is very nice, it smells like Scotch Whisky (peat, smoke), toffee, chocolate, roasted malt, and some iodine and dark fruit.  The brew tastes like peat and smoke (from the Highland Park barrel aging), roasted malt, toffee, and a bit of iodine.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit coating but it does seem a little bit thin to me.  Moderate carbonation.  Drinkability is good, its easy and enjoyable to drink.  I think this is a good brew, but then I also like smoky Scotch Whisky so Im a bit biased.  It is a pricey brew, but I thought it was worth it to try once.

Aroma is inky, iodine, roast coffee, and rich malt, black, small cappuccino head, some nice lace. Flavour is smoky, woody malt, scotch notes, hints of fine liquorice. Medium bodied, very well balanced, roasted bitterness, alcohol is subtle and yet a supper. Terrific!

Bottle. Pours motor oil black, shiny, with a slight, brown head. Dark malt aroma, roasty, some dark fruit, some cocoa, with great whiskey character. Flavor is deep: Sweet, with notes of maple, char, tobacco, chocolate, some oats. Thick, chewy mouthfeel, with light carbonation. Failry warming. Finishes roasty and dry, with some lingering stickiness. Outstanding.

This bottled brew marked #10226 1/2009 from a bottle shop poured a head of foamy fine to medium sized dark brown colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a no visible carbonation opaque black brown colored body and a poor lacing. The aroma was dark malt and whiskey. The semi-flat smooth mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The strong flavor contained notes of vinous whiskey and dark malt. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

Bottle.  Mmm mm mm mm mm!  Pours an oily milky near black with a fizzy soda light tan head.  Slick grassy and whisky aroma, lightly peaty, bold chocolate, just a hint vinous, delicate alcohol, beautiful roast with a hint of aged cherry, the most balanced of the barrel aged olas Ive come had.  Flavor at first is a bit of cola, light grassiness and peat, very balanced, nice chocolate notes, faint roast, some roast bitterness towards the finish, alcohol is very nice, again, like the aroma, this is the most balance Ive had from the ola dubhs.  Medium bodied, fizzy lively carbonation, not oily but more milky.  Very nice and glad I finally decided to buy a bottle.  Im digging this, more like a whisky chocolate phosphate!  Light acidity that is very nice, easily the most balanced of the bunch.

Bottle. Pours a clear, dark brown beer with a beige/lightbrown head. The aroma is roasted, licorice, wood, whisky and coffee. The flavor is very close to the nose. The palate is dry and roasted. Overall a good beer.

Impressive bottle that makes the beer look like you need to buy. Pours a tar black but thin. Brown lingering head. Scents of licorice and dark chocolate. Smoke smokey notes but not overpowering. Starts off thin on the tongue. Maybe because Im use to the imperial stouts. That have lots of residual sugars. Smokey taste right off the bat and a lingering licorice. After taste. Alcohol not very high but I do get bourbon notes as well. It seems like there is something missing but I cant put my finger on it. Overall I would suggest trying another for its price tag is not worth the taste. My opinion.

Pours black with a small brown head; strong whiskeyish aroma: peaty,  oaky and also very fruity, like of dark cherries, lots of roasty chocolate too; flavor is quite roasty, oaky and chocolaty with the finish of licorice, smoke and dark fruits; body is medium with low carbonation, smooth, if not quite oily.

Pours pitch black and completely opaque without even the slightest bit of lighter color when held to a light source and a one finger beige head that slowly fades into a thin ring.

Silky chocolate aroma with a touch of smokey malt, vanilla, earthy oak, bourbon, toffee and lactic cream. There is a perfect amount of barrel presence in the nose providing earthy oak, subtle vanilla and coconut balancing out the roasted malt, burnt toast and coffee bean notes.

Slightly chewy medium body with a very prominent whiskey barrel presence that overtakes the roasted dark malt presence. Underneath there is a very faint viscous chocolate malt character with hints of espresso bean, toffee, oatmeal and burnt toast. The complex balance suggested in the nose is missing here with an overwhelming bourbon presence. Very hot and sweet overpowering the subtle vanilla, caramel and toffee notes. This beer improves as it warms but overall the bourbon is too strong, overpowering the other flavors.
330ml bottle purchased at The Whiskey Shop in Buchanan Galleries Glasgow, Scotland for 4.75 GBP Very good.

(Old BA rate - cask)
Similar in appearance to the other vintages of Ola Dubh in that it is damn near black. But it does have the wonderful tinges of brown. Poured with a thinnish, darker tan head. As anticipated, the whiskey and malt aromas shine the most, but there are some earthy aromas as well and a bit of smoke. Like the smell, the whiskey grabs your attention first, but then gives way to smokey and salty flavors. Fairly thin, and not nearly as oily as other Ola Dubh vintages that Ive tried. Little to no bubbliness (cask), but very pleasant. Not as drinkable as either the 40yr or 30yr IMO. The 18yr just didnt carry the nuances and complexities as well as the other two and therefore each sip was not as interesting as the last. Overall, even though I much prefer the other vintanges, this was still a stellar brew.
Had this one @ Unofficial Dutch Ratebeer Meeting. Black colored brew. Roasted malts, chocolate in the aroma and flavor. Smooth, nice.

Bottle and served in tulip: Deep mahogany with a small creamy head and spotty lace, some oily legs. The aroma has notes of rich brown toasted and bready malts, treacle, sea salt, peat, oak, sherry, hint of pure cacao nibs, fig and apricots. Initial taste is rich dark fruits, heavy scotch imbued malts and wood with a very earthy and old school oxidization. Lovely undertones of dark candi sugar, walnut and mineral water completes the experiance. The one thing about this brew that falls short is the mouth feel, far too thin for the flavor profile and far too oaky and tannic. The alcohol warming is noticeable but not intrusive. I liked this but would put it below the 12 and 16 aged barrels and on par with the 30, can not wait to try the last 40 yo soon.

Bottle. £5 from Utobeer. Interesting aroma. Rich. Chocolate, lots of black cherries, banana, smoke, peat, Scotch whisky, woody including oak cask, engine oil, alcohol, malt, spiciness and treacle. Alcohol notes are very low for an 8% beer. Very dark brown, almost black. Tan head that quickly disappears. Medium bitterness, with notes of sweetness. Very thick, viscous and gloopy. Long finish.
Black with a small tan head. Aroma of licorice, roasted malt and meaty smoke. Full bodied smoke and roast flavour

Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, vanilla, oak, light smoke and chocolate. Flavour is roasted malt, chocolate, cocoa, vanilla and light smoke.
Pours dark brown with a thin brown head.  Smells roasty and bozy with some oak, lots of vanilla.  Tastes f vanilla and boozy with some sweet chocolatey elements on the finish.
Bottle @ Odense Tasting, April 2010. Pours pitch black with a small creamy off white bubbly head. Nose is mainly peat, vague roast and rubber mainly. Some chocolate. Smooth. Nice

Bottle at Dutch RB meeting, thanks for sharing Savad! Pours pitch black with a small off-white head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, leather, caramel, coffee and single malt whisky. Bottle from Feb 09.  Poured very dark with a small offwhite head.  Aroma of whiskey, roasted malt, dark fruit, peat.  Taste is also quite roasty, with a bit of whiskey, dark fruit, earthy peat, and light smoke.  Quite a bit of sweetness as well.  Mouth is full and sweet.  Overall, a nice whiskey flavored brew.

Bottle. The aroma has coffee, whisky, some wood. Black coloured with an off-white head. The taste is sweet, bit salty, has roast, whisky, little fruit, coffee. Medium bodied, could use some more. Nice though.
Bottle at Cardinal, Stavanger. Black, dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is smoked, roasted, malt, oak, whiskey, chocolate, vanilla. Nice beer.

Bottle. 

Dark brown with a small off-white head that dont leave a lot of lacings.

The aroma is of sweet whisky, oak, salty licorice and dark malts.

The flavor is sweet and well balanced, but perhaps a little on the simple side. However, it is very well integrated. The coffee and chocolate flavors from the malts go really well with the subtle sweet fruity whisky aromas. Some cookie-like malts appear in the middle. The finish is mildly bitter and has a delicate warmth to it. Ends with notes of oak, whisky and salty licorice. 

Medium body and comparably lots of carbonation. Wouldve loved it if it had a bigger body.

All in all, a good beer. I really like it when barrel aging results in such a balanced beer. But not complex or big enough to be rewarded with higher grades.
caramel, toast, chocolate, nuts, roasty, herbs, woody, black, brown foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, average carbonation, long finish,

pitch dark, sooth offwhite head.
aroma of peat smoked whiskey, roasted malts, alc adds to the aroma nicely,   whiskey and stout aromas blended. brown sugar VERY nice.
flavor is wood, whiskey, licorice, roasted malts.  pretty brutal flavor, but very nice if you are into smoked whiskey beers.
palate is too thin to handle the powerfull flavor.

Fløska. Very nice pitch balck colour with a small well steady light borwn colour. Sweet deep roasty vinious, dark fruity,nice  whisky woody  bit smoke aroma. Good pleasant mouthfeel. Flavour of whisky and roasted malt along with smoke and some chocolate, Whisky roasty malty dark vfruity finish.

Bottle. Pitch black body with a medium creamy tan head. The aroma is light peaty, port, roasted malt, ripe fruit, whisky and lighter notes of chocolate. The flavour is peat, smoke, light chocolate, roasted malt and some caramel. Not as complex as 12 yo.

Bottled. Black coloured. Dense brown head. Aroa of vanilla, wood, ripe frutis, light caramel and some spice. Flavour of spice, vainlla, wood, light smoke, ripe fruit, tar, light liqourice. Quite complex. Medium to full bodied. light smokey and tarry end. Very nice and drinkable.

Bottle. Medium high creamy and lasting light brown head. Pitch black body. Powerful roasted malt coffee whisky with smoky notes plus wood. Roasted malt with whisky at the front and coffee liquorice in the background in combination with a nice hops bitterness and a hint of smoke. Low carbonation and a long aftertaste.

A smell and taste of whisky, butter, coconut, coffee, licorice and chocolate. Thick, buttery and creamy mouthfeel. Also dry and mouthcoating. A bit to buttery and to much licorice for my taste. The other versions where better.
Good creamy head and nice aroma. A bit smoky aroma with a slight taste of cappuccino and chocolate. Aftertaste abit too quickly vanishing.

Straight up black pour.  
aroma is barrel, vanilla, woody and sweet, some light notes of fruit.  
Flavor is extreme peat smoke.  Smokey and sweet.  Yum.  some sweet barrel notes and vanilla.  Scarily drinkable, really fantastic stuff.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2010 Jblauvs is the man...Nearly completely black pour with a small beige head. The aroma is peaty as fuck. Vanilla, molasses, roasted barley, oak smoke, earth, and straight wood. The flavor is smoke and peat to the max. The peat actually made my balls shrivel. The malt character is huge and pervasive- molasses, brown sugar, oak tannins, and caramel are massive. The palate is rich, thick, and quite full. It sits on the tongue in a sticky, thoroughly lasting fashion.

Thanks to jblauvs for this one. Nearly black pour with a small, bubbly white head. Aroma holds massive amounts of vanilla, peat, wood, molasses, vinous grape, raisin, and plum- excellent. Flavor is awesome; peat, awesome campfire smokiness, dark fruit, and wood. Palate is very drinkable, obscenely tasty. Great brew.
Bottle at home. Black - small brown head. Smokey, chocolate, roasted, light lactose, light youghurt, licorice, dark chocolate, soya, light thin and watery body+mouthfeeling, pleasant.

Bottle from Kris Wines. Jet black pour with light tan head that very quickly dissipates. Smoky aromas of caramel, chocolate, malts. More smoother and not as peaty as the 12 and 16 year old. Flavours of dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, wood. Extremely smooth mouthfeel. Dry, sweet finish. Very nice indeed.

Bottle, Göteborg, Scotisch tasting 2010-02-06
AP: black beer brownish head AR/F:malt and whiskey, sweet vanilla fudge, smoother then the younger ones, woody finish.

Pours black with a slight red tint. Not much of a head that goes to lace quickly. Caramel smoke with a note of spice for aroma. Not much carbonation. Caramel fruit coffee chocolate whiskey with a buttery note. Finishes caramel smoke chocolate, hint of licorice with a hint of dry. The alcohol is fairly well hidden which just a nice tickle. Overall a very smooth brew. I could see where it could use some more fullness, but I wouldnt call it watery as it is. I like it a lot and for sure going to have more.

Bottle at Bishops Arms, Malmö, bottled February 2009Black color; medium creamy head. Very nice aroma, creamy, light smoke, cappuccino, eggnog, alcohol, chocolate, wood. Medium body, lean mouthfeel, rich chocolate flavor, some caramel, light whisky touch, and just some warmth from the alcohol. The aroma is clearly more interesting (8 or 9) than the flavor (not rich enough, 7 or 8) and the final, which indeed is almost boring.

Bottle. Poured clear dark brown color with an average brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Heavy aroma of caramel, whiskey and toasted malt. Medium to full body with smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium toasted sweet flavor with a medium sweet whiskey finish of moderate duration. My expectations were met with a smooth complex brew.
Bevuta al ma che siete venuti a fà.... veramente notevole! lutilizzo delle botti di highland park fa sentire decisamente i suoi frutti...... poke birre sono kosì eleganti...

average creamy light brown head. fair lacing. mostly diminishing. flat average density black body. aroma: heavy malty, milk chocolate, whisky and trufles.if: moderate sweet light bitter. ff: moderate sweet light bitter. average duration. palate: medium full body, oily texture, soft carbonation and metallic finish. aroma bem mais fraco que da 40, parece uma porter, forte gosto de chocolate, leques toques whisky, boa drinkability, disfarça bem o ABV. significa black oil. 80s

Bottled:Pours very dark brown (as good as black) with a creamy head. Aroma is sweet liquorice, tar and ash. Smooth and rounded mouth feel. Flavour is tar, peat and ash leading to a sweet-ish and warming alcohol finish.

Black with some brown coming through, small beige head with little lazing. Aroma is inviting of lightly peaty whisky, wood, roasted malt, liqourice and light caramell. Flavour is weaker with light roasted malt, light peat and wood and liqourice with a slightly dry ending acompanied by lingering whisky notes. Mouthfeel is medium and quite smooth.

Bottle (33 cl) from Systembolaget. Mild roasted aroma with some dark chocolate and salmiak, and notes of whiskey and wood. Medium bodied, low carbonation. Well balanced with a dry and salty finish. Very much like the 12 year variant, much ado for very little.
Bottle. Almost black liquid with a small, beige head. Aroma is a bit sweet with notes of oak and a hint of smoke. Taste is sweet, a bit alcoholic and a bit roasted. Nice.

Bottled. Dark brown almost black with a small firm beige foam. Rich rounded aroma of toasted malts, oak, roasted almonds, prunes, sweet licorice and milky chocolate. Nearly full-bodied with strong notes of malt whiskey, oak, nuts, almonds and roasted malts with touches of anise, toasted bread and mild coconut. Smooth mouthfeel. Long aftertaste of wood, whiskey, roasted almonds, mild anise and toasted malts. Really tasty stuff for sure...

Pours a three finger brown head that leaves some lace. Black, no highlights. Chocolate/whiskey nose. Light-medium carbonation and heavy bodied. Flavor is smooth, roasted chocolate and whiskey. Almost a burnt chocolate finish. Bottled Jan 2009. Worth trying - $10.50 for a 330ml bottle from Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, Me.

33 cL bottle. Pours dark brown to black with a creamytan to chocolate brown head. Aroma is vanilla and dark roasted malty. Smooth whiskey, wooden, light vanilla and smoked. Dry and roasted base flavoured.

Bottle at Green Lion, Malmö.
Black coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Sweet aroma of caramel, dried fruits, liquorice and alcohol with notes of whisky.
Sweet flavour of caramel, dried fruits, whisky and alcohol.
Sweet and alcoholic finish.

Bottle 330ml.Clear dark red brown color with a small to average, frothy - fizzy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, smoke - peat, light chocolate, light licorice, serial soot ash notes. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090823]

0,3 liter fles. bottle number 12242. date jan 2009. Gekregen op mijn verjaardag 22/3/2009 en gedronken op Sinterklaasfeest 28/11/2009. Heerlijk donker bruin bitter bier. botttle 12251. Date jan 2009 heb ik nog in voorraad.

Bottle: Pours a mostly opaque black with dark mahogany edges and a thin, spotty-lacing light tan head.  Aroma is rich with smoky peat and oaky Scotch with some sweet dark caramel malty undertones.  Starts with a nice malty fullness and smoky dark caramel sweetness with just the right amout of oxidation, well-balanced with earthy peat and Scotch barrel flavor before a smooth, slightly warming semi-dry finish.  A very enjoyable scotch barrel-aged brew.

Cask.  Small brown head atop black body with brown edge.  Aroma is moderately sweet, roast/smoke, chocolate, some vanilla.  Taste is moderately sweet, chocolate, roast, some smoke, light vanilla, alcohol.  Medium body, low carbonation, smooth.

Cask at Churchkey. Like its 30 year counterpart, the beer pours a rich, dark color with a tan head. Aroma is more subtle, with notes of vanilla, malts, alcohol peaks in. Not as smooth as I expected, though flavor was still very rich and enjoyable.
Bottle, batch no. 326. Dark brown body, with a large brown head. Aroma is oak, whisky, coffee. Flavor is wood, whiskey, molasses, coffee incl. notes of alcohol. Great beer.

Bottle.  Pours a dense chocolate to mahogany color, nearly black in its oily opaqueness.  A thick, foamy head of mocha colored froth settles slowly to a thick, bubbly ring surrounding a patchy blanket.  Neat, diagonal flares of paper-thin lacing break apart into a sea of spots that cling to the glass.  Aromas of dark chocolate and dry caramel roast are set off by luscious, vanilla laden oak and soft, peaty smoke.  Hints of cola and molasses add further earthy sweetness, while hints of coffee and bitter, earthen hops balance things out.  Flavors are as even-keeled as they come, teetering back and forth between creamy chocolate, caramely malts and smooth, oaky, smoky barrel influence.  Toffee coated hazelnuts lend a certain rich, oily flavor.  The palate is as silky as they come, smooth from start to finish, ending on the drier, smoky side.  Just a bit more body would make the mouthfeel perfect.  This stuff is simply great.  I thought the 16 year old was the best of the bunch until a came across this one, and the balance here is just incredible.  World class beer.

On cask at Churchkey in Washington DC.  Pours a slightly oily, opaque black with a thin, spitty, off white head.  Aroma is nice, boozy, grainy, toast, caramel.  Flavor is better, both the whiskey and the beer come through: wood, booze, whole grains, pumpernickel, whiskey, sour mash, slight smoke, coffee, brown sugar, molasses.  Finish is a little oily but otherwise smooth.  Easier to drink than the 40 year.  A nice compliment between beer and booze.

bottle thanks to bullzeye.  Pours nearly black with a thin head.  Aroma of bourbon, raspberry, chocolate and leather.  Flavor is smokey, leather, some underlying smokey sweetness.  Medium/smooth palate.  I am a fan of the Old Dubh series.

Bottle at Mallaskukko, Turku. Dark brown to black, thin dark beige head. Lots of buttery real vanilla on the nose, woody whisky alcohol, simple but enjoyable. Flavor is wood, licorice, soft and sweetish whisky feel,  dark molasses, slightly coarse salmiak finish. A bit empty palate, same is with all of these. Enjoyable whisky beer, very much in line with the others in the series, maybe slightly heavier on the vanilla.

Big thanks to Peter from Angelicas in Redwood City, who was nice enough to provide us with this excellent beer while we were having a tasting there.  Great guy, good to see more people running quality beer establishments in this area.  Pours black and fairly viscous with a nice tan head.  Great aroma of smoke, chocolate, tobacco, leather, and scotch whisky.  Flavor is similarly complex with lots to it: roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, smoke, Copenhagen tobacco (this is not a bad thing), vanilla, and wood.  Also some Scotch whisky of course.  Rounds out very well.  Body is medium and palate is smooth.  Great beer!

A black colored beer, with a thick almost brown head. By pouring out the whisky flavors are explicit there. The aroma of fruits, with coffee and chocolate. Hints of vanilla. The taste of roasted malts, fruits chocolate and whisky notes in the back with alcohol. The aftertaste is dry with coffee bitter.

Bottle. Deep dark brown color. Malt, whisky, smoke, caramel and vanilla in the aroma. Malty sweet alcoholic flavor with caramel, molasses, peaty malt whisky, chocolate, vanilla and raisin. Some roastbitterness in the finiah. Warming complex beer.

330ml bottle, 2009 vintage, no.12539, enjoyed as an aperitif to lunch at Olympen in Oslo. Deep, dark brown body with ruby highlights. A thin, tan layer on the surface. Inviting aroma of dark vanilla, raisin and liquorice. Rich in flavour with peaty malts up front, developing into a nice taste of coffee and hints of chocolate added by notes of anise. Dry, bittersweet ending that lingers for a long while with a whisky-like tint on the back of the tongue. Very pleasing with a rounded and velvety mouth feel (shared with Øyvind, 13.10.2009).
scura buona schiuma discreta persitenza noaso frutta secca whisky legno toffee poco afumicato in bocca morbida dolcezza frutta secca whisky finale legermente affumicato corpo medio
Nearly a black pour, small off white head. Aroma of bandaids, scotch, and chocolate.  Flavor has iodine, whiskey, chocolate, peat and a salty note.  Not my favorite Ola Dubh but not bad.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2009 Bottle, at Cardinal. It pours a black body under a rapidly diminishing beige head. Oxidation, chocolate and roasted malts on the nose, dried fruits as well. I think the whisky was quite subdued in the nose, but more pronounced in the flavor, where it added a good warmth. Oxidation, vinegar notes, roasted malts and hints of chocolate too. Full-bodied and slightly warming. Roasted, oxidized and chocolate finish with some alcohol. A quite yummy beer that I wont shy away from again. Rating: 7-4-7-4-15--3.7. 090728Bottle, courtesy of fonefan. A clear, dark, dark brown beer with a small, beige head. The nose has peat, coffee, smoke and roasted malts, with some spirits as well. Peaty, lightly smoked flavor with roasted malts and some spirits. Full-bodied, dry and warming. Long, warm finish with peat and roasted malts. A pretty nice one-hour beer. Maybe my rating is a bit influenced by the seventeen low-alcohols and bier-mix getränke we had before this one. 090823

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2014 Bottle at home ... deep black ... thick loose creamy tan head ... roast malt ,whisky and iodine nose ... again a touch of iodine ... sweet roast ... little bitter... definite whisky ... too much whisky
Bottle at home .. fresh nov 2014 .. deep black .. thin tan lacing ... soft sweet roast ... dark malts .. soft chocolate ... nose .. soft chocolat .. dark roast ... dark fruits ... berries .. dark  fruit ...

330 ml bottle @ Cardinal pub.Pours black with tan head.Aroma of roasted grains , oak ,smoky whisky and dark chocolate.The flavor is very soutish , roast,tar,little chocolate with the wood/oak and whisky smoke to add an extra dimension.Medium body.Very nice.

33cl Bottle from De Bierkoning. Black colour, beige head. Aroma of chocolate, sweetness, vanille, alcohol. Flavour is sweet, chocolate, some whisky, light roasted notes, earthy liquorice root in the finish. Soft mouthfeel, low carbonation, medium bodied. This one was a bit too sweet IMO.

Bottle 33 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours a dark brown with a reddish hue and a light brown head. Aroma of whisky, wood, hard roasted malt and tar. Medium body, a little low in carbonation, hard roasted malt, wood and tar accents. No real bitterness. Delicious. 230809
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  The smell is smokey, malts, whiskey, wood, and good.  The look is black in color, beige colored head.  The taste is smoke, malts, whiskey, beef jerky, and wood.

It is black with a red hue and a creamy, light brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, soot, smoke, wood and licorice. The flavor has sweetness and notes of roasted malt, soot, earth. Smoke, soy sauce, burnt wood, licorice, caramel and coffee. Very nice indeed!

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2013 330lm bottle (Kaisla, Helsinki) (7:5:8:4+:15=3.9+)
Very porridgy malty aroma, very mellow whisky, only a touch of wood. Palate is a wonderful dry woodiness - very dry, some husks. A touch of vanilla, but the graininess is fairly prominent. Rerate: 330ml bottle (Drink Shop, Tallinn) (8:5:7+:4+:15=3.9++)
Glorious aroma, just a touch simpler in the taste. Storming, but just a hairs bredth short of wow, which other vintages have achieved.

(bottle - 330 ml - 2009 vintage) Dark black pour with a thin tan head. Aroma is very potent with lots of wood and whiskey notes. Some smoke and vanilla as well. Flavor begins sweet and buttery with lots of roasted malts, oak, and whiskey. Flavors give way to a dark and roasted middle with some coffee in there as well. Smooth finish.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a lazing brown head. The aroma has powerful notes of whiskey, roasted malt, wood, and soy sauce. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of roasted malt, wood, whiskey, burnt coffee, dark chocolate, and soy sauce, leading to a dry roasted finish. The alcohol burns lightly in the top of the throat. Thanks fonefan and Brugmansia for sharing.

Dark brown with red glimts and a tiny beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, smoke and whiskey. Sweet flavour with peated malt, roasted malt, smoke, wood and whiskey notes. Finished sweet and smokey.

Bottle. Nice fat chocolate aroma, tar, peat and some mild smoke. Almost black colour, red shine. Small brown head. The flavour is nicely coffeeish and creamy. Later comes a mild peatiness with some smoke. The mouthfeel is also creamy, low carbonation. Very late coffee aftertaste. Good.
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Deep brown in color with a small beige head. Aroma is of bacon, wood, smoke and roasted malts. Taste is of smoke, roasted malt and whiskey.
(12oz bottle)  Pours a dark brown body with a small beige head.  Aroma of peat/smoke, roasted malt, and scotch.  Flavor of scotch, caramel, smoke, chocolate, and vanilla with a dry oak finish.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  black with a cream head.  nose is oak, smoke and some other great aromas.  nice on the palate with a smokey flavor backed with vanilla and whiskey, light alcohol finish.

Bottle at PIB. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is leather, vanilla, chocolate and some roast. Flavor is chocolate, roast, tobacco, leather. Solid beer, and of course its just how I like my women...18 years old.

(Bottle #619 at Kaisla, Helsinki, on 2009-08-06) Black. Very small and tan coloured head that remains mostly on the side of the glass, Vanilla, roastedness and liquorice in aroma. Full bodied and dry palate with medium carbonation. Ash, roastedness, liquorice, malts, whisky, lightly chocolate, bitterness and wood in taste. Ashy and roasty aftertaste.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Pours a deep dark brown/black with creamy beige head. Aroma of some chocolate, dark fruit, dark roast, tobacco. Flavor of some smoke, wood, dark roast, faint chocolate, tobacco. Mouth feel is heavy body with low-medium carbonation. Overall, a very good beer!
Bottle from Holiday. Black with a creamy brown head. Coffee scotch whiskey chocolate and vanilla aroma and taste with a very smooth mouth feel.
Slick black, charcoal aroma, no head, smooth and burnt.  More charcoal in the sip with dark tobacco.
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Nose is chocolate, peat, brine. Taste is meat smoke, soy, and teriyaki. Solid beer.

Bottle courtesy of bu11zeye.  Dark brown pour. Very warm smell. Hints of whisky with wood. Aged elements. Dark bitter with warm coffee. Some caramel with a bit of smoked flavor as well. Sweet tobacco lingers on the finish. This is very nice.

12oz, I got at chevy chase wine and liquor, Admittedly Ive seen and not purchased the 40m and saw this and was intrigued, since the 18 year mark is far more comon amongst Scotchs.  Pours black with a tan head.  Nose is sweet malty and quite rich.  Taste is sweet, malty and rich with some scotchy peaty notes.  Pretty tasty.

On tap (out of a firkin!) at Brouwers "Great Scotts!" night. Zoe was right, this was one boozy mofo. Poured deep, dark brown, with some bubbles sort of resembling a head on top. Lots of roasty coffee, overpowering the molasses, chocolate and vanilla malts, but still striking a good balance of flavors. It ended up a little dilute, though admittedly I was expecting more of a big stout. Some definite scotch in the flavor, which I really liked - though it was a velvety scotch, almost resembling bourbon more than anything from the UK. Plenty of oak, and very tasty (plus... just cool to get it poured from a firkin. Really good.

330 ml bottle. Black body with a creamy beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and vanilla. Flavor is smooth, rich, sweet, dark malt, roasted, dry fruit, oak, hops, vanilla, molasses and whisky. Full bodied and a long and warming aftertaste. Really nice, I actually found more aroma in the 16 years version but the flavor is smoother. Looking forward to sample these again quite soon.
Firkin at brouwers. Deep black color with no head. Strong chocolate aroma with cooffee undertones. Taste is sweet almost sickly so and really watery smooth.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty licorice and peaty aroma with some hints of wood. Sweetish malty chocolate and licorice flavor with some woody hints and some hints of smoke. Has a roasted malty licorice finish with hints of wood in the aftertaste.
