Aroma is wooden, smoked, ashes, roasted and peaty ntes, Fresh and brutal. Flavour is quite much the same. liquorice and smoke. Quite harsh and brutal actually. 8% ABV kicks in the head.

Bottled (Tuulensuu, bottled 02/2009, #976).
Opaque black color, small brownish head. Smokey, licorice, oaky-vanilla aroma. Roasted, oaky, dry wood, some vanilla, smoke. This is smokey beer, it differs from other Ola Dubhs.

Bottle Pitch black ale with a small, fizzy, light brown head. The aroma is chocolaty, caramely and peaty... very smoky and rich. Full-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and prickly carbonation. The flavor is chocolaty and sweet - too sweet. Nice scotch whisky accents, but not enough alcohol or hop bitterness to dampen down the cloying malts. Sweet, smoky finish.

Bottle. Blackish beer with a light tan head. Peat and light smoke aroma with toffee. Smokey/peaty flavor with light chocolate and light vanilla. Medium bodied. Toffee, peat and light chocolate lingers with a bit of nuttiness.

Bottle. Number 10001 from Jan 2009. Black pour with a ruby tinge around the edges. Spotty tan bubbles on the surface. Aroma is chocolate, smoky, peaty, light iodine, and soft roasted malt. Taste is roasted malt, iodine, light salt, peat, smoky wood, light chocolate, hints of coffee and treacle, and toffee. Body is medium, smooth and creamy. Carbonation is subtle and not distracting. Ends with more treacle, roasted malt, burnt wood, peat, light iodine, coffee, bits of toffee and dark fruit. rather tasty!

330 at uber. pours nearly jet black with a short-lived but dense and attractive tan head that falls away to loose bubbly film. nice big roasty nose of cola, nuts, campfire, and a bit of peat. very light body, considering what you might expect. light, woolly carb. roast, vanilla, nuts, campfire, peat, and darkened caramel on the mid palate. long roasty finish.

Sent in picture to be uploaded. Bottle number 03771 of the Feb. 2009 Batch. My last of the Ola Dubhs after having the 40 year two weeks ago. Pours with a medium brown head over a black body. Head seems to stay longer than other Ola Dubhs. Can smell the chocolate wafting out of my glass from a far. Closer inspection yields dark fruits and fudge, with wet wood, very light peat and Scotch notes. The aroma is not very whiskey-ey, but I actually prefer it to the 40 (which is twice the price I might add. Light brandy notes too. Molasses and minerals. Overall very pleasant. Like other Ola Dubhs, the aroma is superior to the taste. Although this is good, with fudge up front, followed by toffee, dark fruits and a nice round scotch flavor that trails off to a peat stone like minerally finish. Low residual sugars, but not nearly as low as the 40. Some firewood smoke too. Can taste that this is an Island/Highland Scotch and not a Speyside. Mouthfeel is pretty smooth, not silky, but full. Medium to light bubbles. Great, one of my favorite Ola Dubhs, enjoyed more than the 40 for sure!

33 cl bottle at Cardinal, Stavanger - shared with Roger on my birthday. Dark brown, almost black color, moderate brown head. Aroma is, as the 12 and 16, whisky. Flavor is whisky, but not as heavy as the two others. Not as oily as the 12 and 16.

A Mes rate. Bottle at Home. A beautiful black brown with a thin beige head. Aroma is full of rich chewy malt and slight seaweed and salty notes from the whisky. Faint smoky notes too. Lovely. The flavour is almost identical except the whisky comes forward a little. An awesome prickly bite in the finish. Not brimming with complexity but the whisky is integrated superbly and the balance is just right. A really well done brew.

Thin dark brown head of varying sized bubbles.  Minimal carbonation.  Rich malty aroma with lots of roasted grains, plums, butterscoth, a touch of smoke and on a very deep inhale, the hints of scotch whisky in the background.  Very nice.  Color is a very dark chocolate brown.  Body is a bit thinner than expected.  More roasted grains, ash, bitter dark chocolate and some light scotch notes again.  You kind of feel the presence of the scotch in the alcohol presence rather than in the taste.  Rich and malty are what this brew is all about.  Finishes slick and roasty.  A pretty damn good old ale.
This black ale poured with a modest tan head and a strong alcohol and malt aroma. The flavor is coffee, treacle, plum and oak.

Bottle shared by Marcus. Pours black with suspicions of ruby, and a tan head that wandered away. Very dalr malt aroma. Full bodied with mild carbonation. Flavors of scotch and oak.  And dark toaste malt. Hop? Likely. Finishes darkly smooth and oaky. No heat. Drink this and pass on to oblivion.

Biggish dark brown head. Opaque black body goes dark red at edges. Intense milky chocolate and toffee aroma with smoky roasty licorice notes. Dry-sweetish nutty chocolate nougat taste with smoky toffee and licorice notes. Fullish body. Smooth, mild mouthfeel. Complex, clean, and harmonic palate. Bitterish smoky chocolate and licorice aftertaste with salty tar notes. Some marzipan, too. Excellent! Drinkable, interesting, complex, harmonic, and just plain outstandingly good! (0.33l bottle, Olympen.)
Øl og Mat Festival Oslo 2009. Super malty aroma, complex malty sweet taste with some fruity sense, far smokey. Dark coffee colour. Short aftertaste.

Bottle at Oslo Beer Festival 09.
Tar and smoke aroma. Malty body with long lingering smoke, this feels more complex than the 16 year old with some dark fruit and more oakiness. Deceivingly smooth and easy to drink.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2009 Bottle 33 cl, bottled jan 2009. Pours pitch black with a small but lasting tan head and an aroma of sweet ripe fruit )cherries, plums, black currants, oranges, grapes), oak, coffee and wet earth. The taste is very rick, both an earthy, smoky, woody side and a sweet side with hints of cream, chocolate, strong coffee, tobacco, peat, roasted malts, smoked eel and vanilla. A great bitter and smoky/roasty finish, a great beer!

Bottle @ YNWA, Kolding.
Pours deep chestnut brown with a very nice, creamy, beige head. Great lacing. Aroma is sweet, lots of black currants, peity smoke, milky chocolate and roasted malts. Fat and creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is really wonderful. Chocolate, quite softer peity character than the 16. Roasted and milky character in the warming and elegant finish. Very nice.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brune body with a tan head.  Soy, chocolate, whiskey notes, woody with a light smokiness, excellent attenuation, mellow almost reminded me of a cask ale and then i read the label.  Great beer.

Bottle. Haket. Gothenburg. Dark brown/black colour with a beige head. The best of the three I tried (12, 16, 18). Chocolate, toffee, sweetness, dark fruit, smoke/peat, oak, saltiness, a bit of bitterness, roasted finish. Medium bodied but very creamy and smooth.
Bottle from Bierkoning. Dark brown body with thick tan head. Soid nose of chocolate, soap and whiskey. Nice taste of malts, chocolate and vanilla. Smokiness towards the end. Dry finish. Very good.

From bottle at Olympen,Oslo. Black with a light, mousse-like tan head. Vanilla, rum, orange zest aroma. Vanilla and chocolate flavours, bordered by orangey whisky notes, some roast. Sweetish, but the finish is semi-dry. Full-bodied. Very good.

33 cl bottle at Haket, Göteborg. Shared with a friend on April 24, 2009Black color, brown head. Dry, wood, oak, vanilla, alcohol scent. Chocolate, vanilla, malty, raissin, alcohol taste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness.
Bottle. Pitch black with small tanned head. Sweet wine, smoke. Oily. Coffee. Dark chocolate.

Bottle at Sorbon, Stockholm.
Pours black with a tan head.
Smells sweet and whiskey.
To be fair I wanted and expected a heavy imperial stout when I orderd it therefor my judgement might be a bit to harsh, but I think this beer is to thin and to sweet to level with the wiskey flavours.

Bottle. Look: Black. Tan head. Smell: Sweet malt, smokey whiskey. Taste: Sweet, then smokey. Overall: This one lacks in power. Its too sweet and the taste is short lasting. Nice, but still a dissapointment.

330 ml bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. Bottle No. 12610. ABV is 8.0%. Pitch black colour, big tan head. The aroma of the 18  is less distinct than the 12 and 16, notes of sweet malts, almonds, brown sugar and oak, with a moderate roastiness, notes of chocolate and mild coffee. The flavour is excellent, distinct notes of whisky oak cask, peaty smoke, hints of tar, also roasted notes of coffee, liquorice and dark bitter chocolate. Well rounded, with just the right sweetness and a pleasant bitterness in the finish. Yummy!

Name: Ola Dubh 18
Date: February 05, 2009
Mode: Cask
Source: Brick Store Pub
Appearance: black, frothy tan head
Aroma: sweet winey aroma, touch of whiskey and rye, light roasted, touch of oak
Flavor: rich sweet scotch and oak flavor, touch of fruityness from the dark malt, roasty, dark chocolate, oak provides the earthy balance, instantly warming, a bit fumey as it warms, dries out to allow the scotch and oak to regain control, finally settles down after the forth snifter to be a sweet dark chocolate and vanilla stout with scotch and oak balance, and then turns dry and oaky all over again
Overall: like the 16 the 18 has the needed sweetness to pull out the full complexity of the beer
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.8/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4

Cask at RattlenHum, a special version that has seen its first release in NYC. No head on the pour, same color as the rest, looks like syrup. Tons of booze in the aroma, some sweet malt, a pinch of chili peppers. Flavor is boozy, some vanilla, but mostly pure whiskey all the way. Uncomplex, thin, and pretty lame. Having drank this besides 3 of the other 4 this is by far the weakest.
